name: Harold
culturalSignificance: Harold is a name of Germanic origin, traditionally combining 'heri' (army) and 'wald' (ruler). It has historical significance in England, notably associated with King Harold II, the last Anglo-Saxon king before the Norman Conquest.
modernContext: In modern times, Harold is considered a classic name and has maintained a steady level of use. It is perceived as traditional and somewhat old-fashioned, yet it has a timeless appeal that continues to resonate with parents seeking a strong, historical name.
literaryReferences: Harold is a central character in Alfred Lord Tennyson's poem 'Harold' and also appears in various historical novels about the Battle of Hastings.
personality: The name Harold is often associated with leadership, authority, and a strong sense of duty. Those named Harold are perceived as reliable and trustworthy.
symbolism: Harold symbolizes leadership and strength, drawing from its meaning 'ruler of the army'. It holds a sense of nobility and historical weight.
funFact: Harold is often associated with the famous 'Harold and the Purple Crayon' children's book series by Crockett Johnson, which has been beloved by generations of readers.

achievements: Defended England against the Norman invasion
historicFigures.significance: Harold II was the last crowned Anglo-Saxon king of England. His reign ended with his death at the Battle of Hastings.

achievements: Led Allied forces in North Africa
historicFigures.significance: Harold Alexander was a prominent British military leader known for his role in World War II, especially in the North African campaign.

famousQuotes.quote: The battle is not to the strong alone; it is to the vigilant, the active, the brave.
famousQuotes.author: Harold II Godwinson

famousPeople.name: Harold Ramis
famousPeople.awards: BAFTA Award for Best Original Screenplay

moviesAndShows.title: Harold & Kumar Go to White Castle
moviesAndShows.characterDescription: A young investment banker who embarks on a journey with his friend to a fast-food restaurant

moviesAndShows.title: Harold and Maude
moviesAndShows.characterDescription: A young man obsessed with death who forms an unlikely friendship with an older woman

characterQuotes.quote: The things you own end up owning you.
characterQuotes.context: Referring to materialism and life’s values

celestialData.moonPhaseDescription: A time for completion and celebration
celestialData.compatibleSignsDescription: Earth signs that value stability and practicality
celestialData.celestialArchetypeDescription: Embodies qualities of leadership and authority
celestialData.karmicLessons: Learning to balance ambition with compassion
celestialData.soulUrgeDescription: Desire for nurturing and creating a harmonious environment

inspiration.content: Success is not final, failure is not fatal: It is the courage to continue that counts.
inspiration.author: Harold Godwinson
inspiration.context: Reflecting the resilience and leadership of historical figures

booksWithName.title: Harold and the Purple Crayon
booksWithName.author: Crockett Johnson
booksWithName.significance: A classic children's book with imaginative storytelling and creativity

categories.reason: Associated with historical kings and leaders
Continued relevance and use over centuries

v11BlogContent.opening_hook: Harold is a name that conjures images of nobility and leadership. With its roots in the ancient Germanic languages, Harold has been borne by kings and knights, embodying a sense of strength and authority. In modern times, it remains a popular choice for parents seeking a name with historical depth.
v11BlogContent.etymology_meaning: The name Harold originates from the Old English 'Hereweald', which means 'ruler of the army'. It combines 'heri', meaning army, and 'wald', meaning ruler, reflecting its noble and commanding nature.
v11BlogContent.famous_bearers: Famous individuals with the name Harold include King Harold II, the last Anglo-Saxon king of England, and Harold Pinter, the Nobel Prize-winning playwright known for his masterful use of the English language.
v11BlogContent.pop_culture_moments: In pop culture, Harold has been immortalized by the children's book 'Harold and the Purple Crayon', a story beloved for its whimsical and creative storytelling. The name also features prominently in films like 'Harold & Kumar Go to White Castle'.
v11BlogContent.personality_profile: Harolds are often seen as leaders and visionaries. They are typically characterized by their strong sense of duty and responsibility, combined with a practical and grounded nature.
v11BlogContent.variations_nicknames: Variations of Harold include Harald and Herold, while common nicknames are Harry and Hal. These variations offer a range of options for personalization.
v11BlogContent.popularity_data: Harold has consistently ranked among the top names for over a century, peaking in the early 20th century. Its enduring popularity is a testament to its timeless appeal.
v11BlogContent.pairing_suggestions: When considering sibling names, Harold pairs well with other classic names like Henry and Eleanor, or more modern choices like Oliver and Amelia.
v11BlogContent.cultural_context: With its roots in Germanic and Anglo-Saxon history, Harold carries a cultural weight that is both noble and grounded. It has been a name of choice for leaders and thinkers across centuries.
v11BlogContent.final_recommendation: For parents seeking a name with historical significance and timeless appeal, Harold offers a perfect blend of tradition and strength. Its rich history and strong associations make it a compelling choice for any child.
